update.description:
This is the first of the pull requests intended to replace an earlier pull request.  The purpose of this series of pull requests is to do more removal of boost from sdformat.  Each branch builds upon the last one, so we'll end up with a giant octopus merge in the end.

This particular pull request does nothing but cleanup the tree for style.  There should be no functional change here.

* Fix trailing whitespace all over the tree.

    No functional change.

* Add brackets to all control statements.

    This makes the code consistent across the entire
    codebase.  No functional change.

* Fix up style and indentation.

    No functional change, just making the code consistent.

* Update the copyright headers on a bunch of files.
update.title: Remove boost - Cleanup (PR 1/5)

content.raw: Ahh, yes. That explains it.
content.html: Ahh, yes. That explains it.

content.raw: Yeah, I double-checked in emacs, and it looks OK there.  So I think it is just some rendering problem.
content.html: Yeah, I double-checked in emacs, and it looks OK there. So I think it is just some rendering problem.

content.raw: Are you looking at the diff without whitespace? I did the same...
content.html: Are you looking at the diff without whitespace? I did the same...

content.raw: I think this is just a strange bitbucket rendering error...
content.html: I think this is just a strange bitbucket rendering error...

content.raw: This spacing looks weird.
content.html: This spacing looks weird.

content.raw: All the (2) end years were removed on pull request #301. It should just be a matter of merging sdf4 forward and removing any which may have been introduced on sdf5.
content.html: All the (2) end years were removed on pull request #301. It should just be a matter of merging sdf4 forward and removing any which may have been introduced on sdf5.

content.raw: That sounds good.
content.html: That sounds good.

content.raw: For now, I've just backed out my changes (i.e. net result = no changes to copyright years).  If we want to remove the end copyright dates, I'm happy to do it, but I'll do it in a different cleanup series (this one is already complicated enough as it is :).
content.html: For now, I've just backed out my changes (i.e. net result = no changes to copyright years). If we want to remove the end copyright dates, I'm happy to do it, but I'll do it in a different cleanup series (this one is already complicated enough as it is :).

content.raw: Removing the second year has no unintended consequences.
content.html: Removing the second year has no unintended consequences.

content.raw: hg backout seems to be basically the equivalent of what you said, so I took both suggestions :).  I've now pushed that backout onto this branch.
content.html: hg backout seems to be basically the equivalent of what you said, so I took both suggestions :). I've now pushed that backout onto this branch.

This is the first of the pull requests intended to replace an earlier pull request.  The purpose of this series of pull requests is to do more removal of boost from sdformat.  Each branch builds upon the last one, so we'll end up with a giant octopus merge in the end.

This particular pull request does nothing but cleanup the tree for style.  There should be no functional change here.

* Fix trailing whitespace all over the tree.

    No functional change.

* Add brackets to all control statements.

content.raw: By the way, these changes could be backported to sdf4 if we wanted.
content.html: By the way, these changes could be backported to sdf4 if we wanted.

content.raw: I would do an `hg revert -r e5cf0ec --all` to go back to the state of the previous commit, inspect the diff to see if it's all ok, and then `hg commit` the changes
content.html: I would do an hg revert -r e5cf0ec --all to go back to the state of the previous commit, inspect the diff to see if it's all ok, and then hg commit the changes

content.raw: I think it will have to be done with ["backout"](https://www.mercurial-scm.org/wiki/Backout)
content.html: I think it will have to be done with "backout"

content.raw: Should I just do an "hg revert" on that commit?
content.html: Should I just do an "hg revert" on that commit?

content.raw: I'm ready to approve once the copyright year changes are reverted :)
content.html: I'm ready to approve once the copyright year changes are reverted :)

content.raw: Warning: the diff without whitespace leaves out most of what's great about this PR
content.html: Warning: the diff without whitespace leaves out most of what's great about this PR

content.raw: Removing the second year on the copyright looks a lot easier. Is there an attorney we can ask to make sure removing it doesn't have some unintended consequence?
content.html: Removing the second year on the copyright looks a lot easier. Is there an attorney we can ask to make sure removing it doesn't have some unintended consequence?

content.raw: haha nevermind, I was looking at the diff without whitespace :sweat_smile:
content.html: haha nevermind, I was looking at the diff without whitespace

content.raw: oops, indentation here
content.html: oops, indentation here

content.raw: All right, that's fine with me.  I'll leave that commit out when I merge this branch.
content.html: All right, that's fine with me. I'll leave that commit out when I merge this branch.

content.raw:
Diff without whitespace:

#!/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/311/remove-boost-cleanup-pr-1-5/diff?w=1
content.html:
Diff without whitespace:

#!/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/311/remove-boost-cleanup-pr-1-5/diff?w=1

content.raw:
Continuing the copyright end date discussion from the [previous pull request](#!/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/310/remove-boost2/diff#comment-31615990):

I personally prefer leaving the end date off the copyright since it adds some level of busywork, and we maintain lots of repositories. People can look at the version control history to see how often it is updated.

That's my thought.
content.html:
Continuing the copyright end date discussion from the previous pull request:

I personally prefer leaving the end date off the copyright since it adds some level of busywork, and we maintain lots of repositories. People can look at the version control history to see how often it is updated.

That's my thought.
